questions.text: In preparing for a molecular biology exam, a group of medical students reviews the requirements for RNA synthesis. They discuss the role of RNA polymerase and its necessary components to initiate and carry out transcription. To test their understanding, they consider which of the following is not required by RNA polymerase for its function. What does RNA polymerase not require functioning?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primer

 

Option D:

 

  • RNA Polymerase does not require Primer.

  • Below is the generalized diagram of typical eukaryotic gene:

 

 

  • They are DNA dependent RNA Polymerase

  • There are differences between DNAP and RNAP

    • No primer is needed in RNAP (option d)

    • No proofreading activity in RNAP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Template (ds DNA):  RNA polymerase requires a DNA template to synthesize RNA by reading the template strand and synthesizing a complementary RNA strand.

 

Option B. Activated precursors (ATP, GTP, UTP, CTP): RNA polymerase requires nucleoside triphosphates (NTPs) as substrates to build the RNA strand.

 

Option C. Divalent metal ions (Mn2+, Mg2+): Metal ions like Mg2+ are cofactors that facilitate the catalytic activity of RNA polymerase during RNA synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RNA polymerase does not require a primer to initiate transcription. Unlike DNA polymerase, which needs a short RNA or DNA primer to start DNA synthesis, RNA polymerase can begin RNA synthesis de novo on a DNA template.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 395, 397

questions.text: A molecular biology student is reviewing a diagram of the transcription process, specifically focusing on the RNA polymerase (RNAP) complex. This enzyme complex is critical for the synthesis of RNA from a DNA template. The student is asked to identify the region of DNA to which this complex bind to initiate transcription.  Which region of DNA does the RNA polymerase complex bind to?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promotors

 

Option B:

 

  • RNA Polymerase Complex binds specifically to the promoters of transcription and Ïƒ factor helps in the binding of RNA polymerase complex to promoters as shown in the picture.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Enhancers: These are sequence elements which increase the rate of transcription of eukaryotic genes located both upstream and downstream of the transcription start site and also within the transcribed protein coding portions of some genes.

 

Option C. Introns: The sequence of a mRNA-encoding gene which is transcribed but excised before translation.

 

Option D. Exons: In many eukaryotic transcription units, which are the portion of a gene that is copied by RNA polymerase often consists of coding regions of DNA (exons) interrupted by intervening sequences of noncoding DNA (introns).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RNA polymerase complex initiates transcription at promoters, which are specific DNA sequences located upstream of the coding region of a gene. Promoters contain specific sequences that signal the RNA polymerase where to begin transcription, and they are crucial for the correct initiation of gene expression.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 395-397.

questions.text: A biochemist is examining the regulation of gene expression in a human cell line. Specifically, the focus is on the initiation phase of transcription in protein-coding genes. Identifying the key protein factor that recognizes promoter regions is crucial for their research. Which protein factor is known to identify the promoter of protein-coding genes in eukaryotes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TFIID

 

Option B:

 

 

  • The general transcription factor, TFIID recognizes and binds to the core promoter elements such as the TATA-box in eukaryotic protein-coding genes and these genes are transcribed by RNA polymerase II.
  • In eukaryotes, there are at least 7 transcription factors, collectively called as Tf-II.
  • First, the TATA box is recognized by TBP (TATA binding protein) →TBP-associated factors (TAF) bind with TBP to form TFIID.
  • Binding of TFIID complex to the TATA box is the first step in the transcription process.
  • Other proteins associated with the process are, TFIIA, B, E, F, H, and polymerase II.
  • The whole complex spans DNA from position -30 to +30. Moreover, other proteins, known as general transcription factors (GTFs) facilitate promoter specific binding to form preinitiation complex in mammals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pribnow box: It is a cis-acting element in prokaryotic promoters.

 

Option C. Rho: It is involved in the termination of prokaryotic transcription.

 

Option D. Sigma: It is the subunit of prokaryotic RNA polymerase that recognizes and binds the prokaryotic promoter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TFIID is essential in eukaryotic transcription initiation, recognizing and binding to the TATA box within gene promoters. This action recruits additional transcription factors and RNA polymerase II, initiating transcription.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 590, Lippincott 7/e: p 430

choices.text: Increases its affinity for non-promoter DNA

questions.text: What is the role of the Sigma factor in the prokaryotic cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) For initiation of transcription 

 

Option B:

 

 

  • DNA-Dependent RNA Polymerase or RNAP binds to the promoter site and initiates transcription.
  • It has a core complex consisting of 2 identical α subunits, 2 large β and β′ subunits, and an ω subunit, in which the β subunit binds Mg2+ ions and composes the catalytic subunit.
  • Core RNA polymerase ββ’α2 ω - termed E + sigma [σ] factor to form holoenzyme, ββ’α2 ω σ or E σ.
  • The σ subunit enables the core enzyme to recognize and bind the promoter region to form the preinitiation complex (PIC).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. For termination of transcription: This happens with the help of specific signals which are recognized by a termination protein known as Rho factor. Rho independent termination is also present.

 

Option C. Act as promoter sequence:  It can only recognize the promoter site and increases the affinity of the holoenzyme towards the promoter site.

 

Option D. Increases its affinity for non-promoter DNA: Sigma factors have a dual role in the process of promoter recognition; σ association with core RNA polymerase decreases its affinity for non-promoter DNA while simultaneously increasing holoenzyme affinity for promoter DNA.  

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sigma factor is a protein needed for the initiation of transcription in prokaryotes. It is a component of the RNA polymerase holoenzyme that binds to specific promoter sequences in the DNA, allowing RNA polymerase to initiate transcription at the correct site.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 397, Lippincott 7/e: P 419.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is an inhibitor of DNA to RNA transcription?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rifampicin

 

Option D:

 

Rifampicin is an antibiotic that inhibits bacterial RNA polymerase, effectively blocking the transcription of DNA into RNA. It binds to the β-subunit of RNA polymerase and prevents the initiation of transcription, making it a potent transcription inhibitor.

 

Inhibitors of RNA Synthesis

 

  • Actinomycin- D
  • Mitomycin
  • Rifampicin
  • Alpha Amanitin
  • 3' –deoxyadenosine

 

Explanation:

Option A. Novobiocin: This is an inhibitor of DNA gyrase, an enzyme involved in DNA replication, not transcription.

 

Option B. Puromycin: This antibiotic mimic the 3'-end of an aminoacyl-tRNA and interferes with translation by causing premature chain termination, not transcription.

 

Option C. Ciprofloxacin:  This drug inhibits DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, enzymes involved in bacterial DNA replication and supercoiling, not the transcription process.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During a study session on transcription, a student examines a segment of DNA to determine how it would be transcribed into RNA. They focus on a particular coding strand region with the sequence 5’-CGT-3’ and aim to identify the corresponding RNA sequence that would be produced. What is the correct RNA sequence transcribed from this DNA coding strand?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5’-CGU-3’

 

Option A:

 

Template / AntiSense / Non-Coding / Minus Strand

 

  • Template strand: as new RNA is getting synthesized using this strand as template

 

Non-Template / Sense / Coding / Plus Strand

 

  • Coding strand: as it has the same codons as new RNA (see fig)
  • Sense strand: as it has same sense of direction as new RNA (see fig)

 

 

  • As it is mentioned in the question as coding strand region, the RNA product is the same as coding region except in the b

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. 5’-GCA-3’: This sequence is complementary to the given DNA sequence but doesn't account for the RNA uracil substitution for thymine.

 

Option C. 5’-ACG-3’: This sequence is a reverse complement of the given DNA sequence and does not represent the RNA sequence transcribed from the given DNA coding strand.

 

Option D. 5’-UGC-3’: This sequence is the reverse and complementary (with T replaced by U) of the given DNA coding strand, which is not how transcription works. Transcription generates a sequence complementary to the template strand, which would be identical to the coding strand with U in place of T.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During transcription, RNA polymerase reads the template strand of DNA (which is complementary to the coding strand) and synthesizes RNA in the 5' to 3' direction. The RNA sequence is complementary to the DNA template strand and thus will be identical to the DNA coding strand, except that in RNA, uracil (U) is substituted for thymine (T).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 395.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient suffering from chills, vomiting and cramping was rushed to the casualty. He had eaten wild mushrooms for dinner that he had picked earlier in the day. His symptoms are due to an inhibition of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA polymerase II

 

Option B:

 

  • The patient has ingested alpha-amanitin, a toxin, at very low concentrations, inhibits RNA polymerase II and blocks the transcription of single-copy genes.
  • The inability to synthesize new proteins in all cells causes the symptoms.
  • Amanitin poisoning initially causes gastrointestinal disturbances à electrolyte imbalance and fever à liver and kidney dysfunction.
  • Death occurs within 2 to 3 days after ingestion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. RNA polymerase I: This enzyme is responsible for the transcription of rRNA, and while its inhibition would affect protein synthesis, it is not the primary target of α-amanitin.

 

Option C. RNA polymerase III: This enzyme synthesizes tRNA and some other small RNAs. Its inhibition would also impact protein synthesis but is not the primary mechanism of toxicity in this scenario.

 

Option D. DNA primase: DNA primase synthesizes RNA primers necessary for DNA replication. Inhibition of DNA primase would disrupt DNA replication but is not related to the toxic effects of the mushrooms in question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The toxin α-amanitin found in these mushrooms inhibits RNA polymerase II, which is essential for the synthesis of mRNA in eukaryotic cells.

questions.text: Among the listed eukaryotic promoter/regulatory elements, which one exhibits the greatest variability in position relative to the transcription start site?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Enhancer

 

Option B:

 

Enhancers are regulatory DNA sequences that can significantly increase the efficiency of transcription initiation from a promoter. They are notable for their ability to function at variable distances from the promoter, sometimes even tens of thousands of base pairs away, and can be located upstream, downstream, or even within the gene they regulate. Their position relative to the start site of transcription is highly variable, and they can exert their effects in an orientation-independent manner.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Downstream promoter element (DPE): The DPE is located relatively close to the core promoter, usually within about 30 base pairs downstream of the transcription start site, and its position is not as variable as that of enhancers.

 

Option C. Initiator sequence: The initiator (Inr) sequence is a core promoter element that is located precisely at the transcription start site and serves as a binding site for transcription factors and RNA polymerase II.

 

Option D. Operator: Operators are DNA sequences that interact with repressors to control the transcription of adjacent genes, mainly in prokaryotes. In eukaryotes, similar regulatory elements are part of the promoter or enhancers but are not typically referred to as operators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Eukaryotic promoters are much more complex than bacterial promoters.
  • The most common bacterial promoter elements are the –10 and –35 sequences, which are the recognition sites for RNA polymerase binding.
  • In addition, the bacterial promoters may have operators (repressor binding sites) and activator binding sites.
  • Eukaryotic promoters have a core region that may contain a TATA box (which is bound by TBP, the TATA binding protein), an initiator sequence, and downstream promoter elements.
  • In addition, eukaryotic promoters have upstream elements such as GC boxes and CCAAT boxes which bind specific transcription factors (Sp1 and CTF, respectively).
  • Enhancers are elements that increase or enhance the rate of transcription initiation from a promoter. Enhancers can be upstream or downstream of the transcription start site and can exert their effect from hundreds or thousands of bases away and also they are orientation-independent (ie, whether their recognition sequence is on the Watson or Crick strand).

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 608-610
